image.altText: Two indigenous teenagers with painted faces link arms in outback setting

items.synopsis: Twelve months after committing to a Voice referendum during last year's Garma Festival, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is drumming up support for the Yes campaign at this year's festival. Follow live.

title.children: Anthony Albanese tells Garma Festival to 'vote Yes for a better future' in keynote speech

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Public polling has shown that the Yes vote is declining, yet the PM is not backing down from going ahead with the vote this year. Why? Patricia Karvelas writes: "The prime minister will not blink, staring down calls for a rethink on the timing of the Voice referendum and honouring his commitment to Indigenous Australians that he is a man of his word. He has made clear that fear of a loss will not stop him from keeping his word to the late Yolngu leader and land rights legend Yunupiŋu." Read the full analysis below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Risk of defeat is not deterring Albanese

featuredLink.title: PM stares down calls for rethink on timing of the Voice referendum

props.alt: Anthony Albanese raises his hand to wave at the crowd while giving a speech on stage

children.content: Public polling has shown that the Yes vote is declining, yet the PM is not backing down from going ahead with the vote this year. Why?
"The prime minister will not blink, staring down calls for a rethink on the timing of the Voice referendum and honouring his commitment to Indigenous Australians that he is a man of his word.
He has made clear that fear of a loss will not stop him from keeping his word to the late Yolngu leader and land rights legend Yunupiŋu."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Albanese said that while the yes-campaign will continue on, Australians should be equally clear on what voting no means. "It is more of the same. Not only rejecting the opportunity to do better, but accepting that what we have is somehow good enough," he said. "An eight year gap in life expectancy in the land of the fair go. A suicide rate twice as high in the lucky country. Shocking rates of disease in a nation with some of the world's best healthcare. Only four out of 19 closing the gap targets on track." "Surely no leader can honestly say that is good enough."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Voting no means 'more of the same', PM says

children.content: Albanese said that while the yes-campaign will continue on, Australians should be equally clear on what voting no means.
"It is more of the same. Not only rejecting the opportunity to do better, but accepting that what we have is somehow good enough," he said.

"An eight year gap in life expectancy in the land of the fair go. A suicide rate twice as high in the lucky country. Shocking rates of disease in a nation with some of the world's best healthcare. Only four out of 19 closing the gap targets on track."
"Surely no leader can honestly say that is good enough."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "There will be no delaying or deferring of this referendum", the PM said in his address to the crowd at Garma. "We will not deny the urgency of this moment. We will not kick the can down the road, we will not abandon substance for symbolism or retreat to platitudes at the expense of progress." It's a "once-in-a-generation opportunity" to make change, he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The referendum will take place this year, PM reiterates

children.content: "There will be no delaying or deferring of this referendum", the PM said in his address to the crowd at Garma.
"We will not deny the urgency of this moment. We will not kick the can down the road, we will not abandon substance for symbolism or retreat to platitudes at the expense of progress."

image.altText: Indigenous Australians in traditional dress performing a traditonal dance during an opening ceremony

items.synopsis: When Anthony Albanese confirmed at the Garma Festival 12 months ago that his new government would go ahead with a referendum on Indigenous recognition and an Indigenous Voice, the Arnhem Land air seemed full of optimism. Since then, things have not been going well, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: The Voice was supposed to unify Australians. Where has the optimism gone?

image.altText: Woman with long grey hair wears Indigenous head piece and large earrings and gazes away from camera

items.synopsis: Marion Patterson was scouted while stacking chairs two years ago. Now, she graces the catwalk with her junglefowl Dreaming dance and extraordinarily unique style.

title.children: At 68, model Marion Patterson dances her Dreaming on the catwalk

image.altText: Anthonty Albanese wearing a pink shirt and a wide brimmed hat surrounded by red flags and people in body paint.

items.synopsis: In a speech at the Garma Festival, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese promises to hold the Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum this year, rejecting calls to delay or cancel it.

title.children: 'We will not deny the urgency of this moment': Albanese promises to hold Voice referendum in 2023

image.altText: Putin poses against a tree, dressed in outdoorsy clothing

items.synopsis: Russia's president may have placed himself at the pinnacle of a so-called "power vertical", but some believe one "humiliating" weekend could be the beginning of the end for his regime.

title.children: 'Absolute dismay and confusion': A picture is emerging of Putin in crisis. It could threaten his rule

image.altText: auction sign out from of two storey home

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank's mission to bring inflation down to its target range of between 2 and 3 per cent appears to be on track, but how confident of this can we be? Movements in the Australian dollar give us some clues, writes David Taylor.

title.children: What the fall in the Australian dollar tells us about the future of interest rate rises

image.altText: A man in a grey jumper sits on a bed in a room with a tv, and paintings on the wall.

items.synopsis: There's a common cycle for many children in this town: Crime, watch house, detention. Background Briefing investigates why.

title.children: Marty woke to find three intruders in his bedroom. His story is one of hundreds from his hometown

image.altText: Smiling Caucasian man, thick black glasses Indigenous art behind, red tie, pocket hankerchief, black suit, slicked brown hair.

items.synopsis: Far from the shining blue of the New South Wales coast, the rich red dirt of Central Australia is steeped in the memory of a man whose legacy lives on through friendships, dialysis and the future of Indigenous art.

subjects.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Art

image.altText: A woman holds Australian flags at a soccer match.

items.synopsis: An international appeal has secured enough supply of a rare combination of blood types to make critical surgery possible for an Adelaide mother.

image.altText: A Wallabies player holds the ball as he collides with an All Blacks opponent.

items.synopsis: The All Blacks strike soon after half-time in the second Bledisloe Cup Test in Dunedin, with the Wallabies looking to record their first victory over their trans-Tasman rivals on New Zealand soil since 2001. Follow our live ScoreCentre.

image.altText: A bowl of steaming rice.

items.synopsis: The Indian rice export ban, the war in Ukraine and El Niño are combining to create a "doom loop" for the world's poorest people, as staple food prices soar.

title.children: The price of rice is skyrocketing, and it's pushing millions more people towards starvation

image.altText: Shane Drumgold holding a folder walking into ACAT.

title.children: The ACT's top prosecutor sparked the Bruce Lehrmann inquiry. Now he's copping most of its fallout

image.altText: Black and white photo of men near satellite

items.synopsis: Voyager 2 was exploring interstellar space 19 billion kilometres away from Earth when an erroneous command caused it to tilt its antenna way from earth.

image.altText: Two young men in woggles and hats hold up ginger beer at a scout camp.

image.altText: An elderly male actor on a red carpet, looks expressionless towards photographers

image.altText: a man and a woman smile at the camera standing in front of a triple j sign

image.altText: The Russian Navy's large landing ship Olenegorsky Gornyak underway at night.

image.altText: A man in a football helmet runs with a ball.

image.altText: A woman in a heavy coat and a beanie crosses her hands with index fingers pointed as she sits next to a grinning man in a jacket

items.synopsis: Europe and parts of north and south America are in the middle of a vicious heatwave, and the world recorded its hottest July on record — but in the Pacific, puffer jackets are becoming the norm as Tonga shivered through its second-coldest temperature on record.

title.children: Puffer jackets in the Pacific Islands — what is going on with the weather?

image.altText: Three people stand by the side of the road holding 'save lee point' posters. They are happy.

image.altText: A police crime scene.

image.altText: Two men walk off a footy field arm in arm.

image.altText: A close up photo of a woman in elasticated waist pants holding her hands on her stomach

image.altText: Pharmacist hands holding a slim box of pills

image.altText: Kiyah sits in the drivers seat of her car, smiling.

items.synopsis: Demand for driving lessons is strong among women, but a lack of female instructors is putting some of them off taking the test.

title.children: Many women prefer to use female driving intructors, and that's holding them back from getting their licences

image.altText: A composite image showing two physicists and the Nagasaki mushroom cloud.

items.synopsis: The story of the first nuclear weapons is, in some respects, the story of a human chain reaction behind an atomic one. With scientists sharing information about the feasibility of a bomb, a crucial moment occurred in 1941, when Australian scientist Mark Oliphant met with American physicists in California.

title.children: An Australian helped shift Oppenheimer 'from the shadows of theory' to the Manhattan Project

image.altText: Anthony Albanese, wearing a brown akubra hat and blue shirt, sits with a woman and man clapping

title.children: Federal government commits $6.4m for 'world-class' Garma Institute

image.altText: Two people holding big fish.

items.synopsis: For a long time a lot of the region's wild-caught barra was sent to southern states for processing, but Darwin's first major fish processing facility aims to cut the distance fresh seafood travels before hitting local plates.

title.children: Darwin barramundi facility aims to cut waste, reduce food miles
